1.name: > Hand Labour vs. Steam Power (Victorian Britain)

12.name: No shortage of labour in Victorian Britain
Low wages; no labour shortage; high wage cost position
Industrialists avoided machines requiring large capital

13.name: Demand for intricate designs (specific styles like hammer varieties)
Upper classes preferred handmade goods (for refinement/class)
Machine goods mostly for export to colonies

14.name: Industries: Gas works, breweries, cold makers, book binders (Christmas)
Preferred hired labour; employing workers for the season

15.name: Job acquisition depended on kin/friendship networks
Many waited weeks; dip in labour market triggers hardship
Seasonally most prominent periods without work
Wages increased but not with rising prices (Napoleonic Wars)
Fear of unemployment led to hostility toward new technology
Example: Women attacking Spinning Jenny in woollen industry

7.name: > East India Company Control over Weavers (1760s+)
> Manchester Comes to India (Decline of Indian Textiles)

31.name: Silk and cotton goods dominated international market
Fine varieties from India in great demand
Where trade was vital (Punjab & Central Asia) and sea (Surat, Hoogly, Masulipatnam)
Indian merchants/bankers financed and controlled network

32.name: European Companies gained power and monopoly rights
Growth of new colonial ports (Bombay, Calcutta)

33.name: System of advances for securing raw cotton
Appointed gomasthas (paid servants) to oversee weavers
Prevalent system: loans dealing with the buyers (system of advances) became coercive
Weavers forced cloth with penalties (indiscipline punished)
Weavers revolted, deserted villages, or took up agriculture

34.name: British industrialisation imposed decline; mill Manchester goods in Britain
British manufacturers sold in Indian markets (imports soared)
Two problems for weavers: 1) import market collapsed, 2) local market shrank (flooded with cheap Manchester imports)
Raw cotton shortage (1860s) due to US Civil War, Britain turned to India; prices shot up
Final blow: Factories in India began production (late 19th century)
